summary: This is an internal email from a Deputy Chief in the U.S. Attorney's Office, Southern District of New York, discussing preparations for a mock presentation or jury exercise related to the Ghislaine Maxwell case. It concerns the use of real or fake names for presenters and lists key case figures to be presented to prospective jurors.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Listed as a key name to be presented to prospective jurors in a mock presentation related to her criminal case.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Listed as a key name to be presented to prospective jurors in a mock presentation, indicating his central role in the underlying case.

persons.name: Victim
persons.context: Listed as a category of person (likely representing generic or anonymized victims) to be presented to prospective jurors in the mock exercise.

connections.description: Both are listed together as key names in a mock jury presentation for the Maxwell case, indicating their alleged partnership in criminal activity.

events.title: Preparation for Mock Jury Presentation
events.description: Internal email coordination regarding an upcoming mock presentation or jury exercise, involving decisions on name usage and roles.

locations: U.S. Attorney's Office, Southern District of New York
keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office was conducting trial preparation exercises, such as mock presentations, for the Ghislaine Maxwell case as of September 2021.
Prosecutors discussed the strategic use of real or fake names for presenters to 'humanize' themselves, mirroring courtroom practice.
The key names to be presented to prospective jurors in the exercise were Ghislaine Maxwell, Jeffrey Epstein, and 'Victim' (with space for fake names).
The correspondence reveals internal procedural planning within the prosecution team ahead of Maxwell's trial.
